item.title: WHO chief Tedros narrowly escapes bombardment at Yemen's Sanaa airport - Hindustan Times
item.description:
WHO Chief Tedros Survives Bombardment at Yemen's Sanaa Airport

Date: Dec 27, 2024 06:48 AM IST | Source: Hindustan Times

World Health Organization (WHO) Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus narrowly escaped an aerial bombardment at Sanaa International Airport in Yemen, which resulted in the deaths of at least two individuals.

  • Tedros and colleagues were about to board a flight when the attack occurred.
  • One crew member was injured during the incident.
  • UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres condemned the attack and called for respect for international law.
  • Airstrikes by the Israeli Air Force targeted Houthi military infrastructure in Yemen, including the airport.
“Our mission to negotiate the release of UN staff detainees and to assess the health and humanitarian situation in Yemen concluded today… At least two people were reported killed at the airport.” - Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus

This tragic event highlights the precarious situation in Yemen, where conflict continues to pose significant threats to civilians and humanitarian missions.

item.title: Bashar al-Assad's Wife Asma 'Severely Ill' With Cancer, Has 50 Per Cent Survival Chance: Report - News18
item.description:
Asma al-Assad Reportedly Severely Ill with Cancer

Date: December 26, 2024

Source: News18

Asma al-Assad, the wife of ousted Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, is reported to be critically ill due to relapsed acute myeloid leukemia, with a 50% chance of survival. She is currently isolated in Moscow to reduce the risk of infection.

  • Asma al-Assad has been diagnosed with acute myeloid leukemia, an aggressive form of cancer.
  • She had previously been treated for breast cancer and was declared free of the disease in 2019.
  • Reports indicate that her leukemia has returned following a period of remission.
  • Medical professionals have isolated her to minimize infection risks.
  • An unnamed source stated, "Asma is dying" and emphasized the severity of her condition.
“When leukemia comes back, it’s vicious. She has been 50/50 in the last few weeks.”

The Kremlin has denied rumors regarding her personal life and her husband's situation.

item.title: Sneak peek into Ivanka Trump's chic Christmas Eve at Mar-a-Lago with DJ Donald Trump - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Ivanka Trump's Chic Christmas Eve Celebration at Mar-a-Lago with DJ Donald Trump

Publication Date: Dec 27, 2024
Source: Hindustan Times

Ivanka Trump celebrated Christmas Eve at Mar-a-Lago with her family while her father, Donald Trump, performed as the DJ. The celebration included festive music and a glamorous family presence.

  • Ivanka wore a stunning black dress with a white flower print.
  • Donald Trump played a variety of songs, including holiday classics.
  • The entry price for the event was $350 per ticket.
  • Guests included Ivanka Trump's husband Jared Kushner and their three children.
  • Notably absent were other family members like Don Jr. and Eric Trump.
“The president played a serious set and was very into the music.” - Source

The event was marked by a festive atmosphere, a limited number of guests, and an affectionate moment between Ivanka and her father.

item.title: Vivek Ramaswamy steps in as Sriram Krishnan's controversial views on immigration spark debate - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Ramaswamy Addresses Immigration Controversy Sparked by Krishnan's Views

Date: December 26, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

Amid controversy surrounding Sriram Krishnan's statements on immigration, Vivek Ramaswamy has elaborated on the dynamics of tech hiring policies, emphasizing a cultural issue rather than a perceived American capability deficit.

  • Ramaswamy criticized the American culture for prioritizing mediocrity over excellence.
  • He remarked that the current cultural values may hinder the recruitment of top technical talent.
  • Krishnan has faced backlash for suggesting the removal of country caps on green cards for skilled immigrants.
  • Trump's AI czar clarified that Krishnan advocates a merit-based immigration process instead of a complete removal of caps.
“If we pretend like it does, we’ll have our a**es handed to us by China.” – Vivek Ramaswamy

The discussion around these immigration policies highlights the need to shift cultural narratives to attract top talent in technology sectors, as indicated by Ramaswamy's comments and the ongoing discourse within political circles.

item.title: Russia “Shoots Down” F-16 Fighter Jet In Zaporizhia Region; Was Ready To Launch Missile: Russian Media - EurAsian Times
item.description:
Russia 'Shoots Down' F-16 Fighter Jet In Zaporizhia Region; Was Ready To Launch Missile: Russian Media

Date & Source: October 2023, Russian News Agency TASS

A US-made F-16 aircraft was shot down in the Zaporizhia region while preparing to launch a missile strike, according to reports. This incident marks the second loss of an F-16 for Ukraine, highlighting ongoing challenges in securing air support.

  • The F-16 was shot down as it was poised to strike.
  • This was the second F-16 loss for Ukraine, the first occurring in August.
  • Deliveries of promised Belgian F-16s to Ukraine have been delayed until 2025.
  • Factors for the delay include a lack of trained pilots and spare parts shortages.
  • Ukrainian pilot training is focusing on younger cadets, potentially delaying operational capabilities.
“The F-16 aircraft was in position to launch a missile strike on the region, and it was shot down.” - Vladimir Rogov

The situation underscores the complex dynamics of air defense and aircraft supply in the Ukraine conflict, with ongoing training and operational delays impacting military readiness.

item.title: Israel hits Sanaa airport and other Houthi targets across Yemen - Euronews
item.description:
Israel hits Sanaa airport and other Houthi targets across Yemen

Publication date: Not specified, Source: Not specified

The Israeli army conducted airstrikes against Houthi targets in Yemen, including major facilities in the capital Sanaa, as a response to escalating missile and drone attacks from the Iran-backed group.

  • The airstrikes targeted Sanaa International Airport, two major power plants, and ports on Yemen's western coast.
  • Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and defence officials approved the military action.
  • The missile launched from Yemen activated air raid sirens in central Israel but was intercepted before causing damage.
  • Prior incidents included a missile hitting a playground in Tel Aviv, injuring 16 people.
  • Israel's foreign minister has called for a UN Security Council meeting to address Houthi aggression and Iranian support.
“These infrastructures were used by the Houthi terror regime to transfer Iranian weapons to the region and for the entry of senior Iranian officials,” IDF statement.

These airstrikes signify a significant escalation in the regional conflict and a direct response to Houthi provocations against Israel.

item.title: Big danger for Pakistan as Taliban declares war against Islamabad as revenge against deadly airstrikes, sends - India.com
item.description:
Taliban Threatens Pakistan Following Airstrikes: 15,000 Fighters Mobilized

Publication Date: December 26, 2024 | Source: India.com

Pakistan faces escalating tensions as the Taliban retaliates against airstrikes aimed at the Tehreek-i-Taliban Pakistan (TTP). This conflict could significantly impact both nations' stability.

  • The Taliban has mobilized 15,000 fighters towards Pakistan's borders in response to recent airstrikes.
  • Pakistan's airstrikes were targeted at TTP camps in Afghanistan, asserting the need to protect its citizens.
  • Several recent terrorist attacks have led to civilian casualties in Pakistan, heightening the urgency of the situation.
  • Afghanistan has expressed strong protest to Pakistan over these military actions.
“Taliban is in no mood to spare Pakistan, ready to bite the hands of those that fed and nourished them.”

This situation underscores the volatile nature of regional geopolitics and the potential for further conflict if diplomatic solutions are not sought.

item.title: Govt imposes restrictions on import of low ash metallurgical coke for 6 months | Company Business News - Mint
item.description:
Govt imposes restrictions on import of low ash metallurgical coke for 6 months

Date: December 26, 2023 Source: PTI

The government has announced import restrictions on low ash metallurgical coke for six months, effective from January 1, 2025, to June 30, 2025. This includes quantitative restrictions from various countries.

  • Import restrictions apply to low ash metallurgical coke.
  • Quantitative restrictions are set for imports from countries such as Australia, China, Colombia, and others.
  • High ash content coke (above 18%) is not subject to these restrictions.
  • The imports will require authorisation from the Directorate General of Foreign Trade (DGFT).
  • Quarterly monitoring will ensure that imports do not exceed specified quotas.
"The country-wise QR will be effective from January 2025 and will cease automatically on June 30, next year."

This measure aims to regulate the import of low ash metallurgical coke and ensure compliance with trade remedies.

item.title: Israel Retaliates Against Houthis Missile Attacks, Strikes Yemen's Sana'a Airport - News18
item.description:
Israel Strikes Yemen's Sana'a Airport in Response to Houthi Missile Attacks

Date: December 27, 2024 | Source: Haaretz

The Israeli military conducted airstrikes at Sana’a International Airport and Hodeidah seaport in Yemen, marking a significant retaliation against a series of missile attacks by the Houthi movement targeting Israel.

  • The strikes occurred after a week of missile launches by the Houthis, including a hypersonic ballistic strike on Tel Aviv.
  • The IDF stated that the military infrastructure used by Houthis for military purposes was targeted.
  • Israel's military actions are viewed as a response to ongoing attacks aimed at its territory, indicating a serious escalation in the conflict.
  • Future military operations are reportedly under consideration involving coordination with the United States.
“Following the approval of operational plans by the Chief of the General Staff, the Minister of Defense and the Prime Minister, IAF fighter jets conducted intelligence-based strikes on military targets belonging to the Houthi terrorist regime on the western coast and inland Yemen.” — Israel Defense Forces

This incident underscores the escalating tensions in the region, reflecting the ongoing hostilities between Israel and Houthi forces.

item.title: India Approved Defence Purchases Worth Rs 4.2 Lakh Crore In 2024 — HAL, L&T, Mazagon Dock Major Winners - NDTV Profit
item.description:
India Approved Defence Purchases Worth Rs 4.2 Lakh Crore In 2024 — HAL, L&T, Mazagon Dock Major Winners

Publication Date: 2024

Source: Bloomberg Quint

India has approved defense acquisitions amounting to Rs 4.22 lakh crore till November this year, benefiting major domestic companies.

  • The Defence Acquisition Council (DAC) and Defence Procurement Board (DPB) approved 40 Capital Acquisition proposals totaling Rs 4,22,129.55 crore.
  • 94% of the total outlay is to be procured from indigenous sources.
  • The Defence Ministry's budget for fiscal 2024 is Rs 6.22 lakh crore, 5% higher than the previous year.
  • 75% of the capital procurement budget is earmarked for the domestic industry.

The government aims to advance local technological capability and reduce reliance on foreign powers.

“Defence Acquisition Council (DAC) and Defence Procurement Board (DPB), during 2024, accorded Acceptance of Necessity (AoN) for 40 Capital Acquisition proposals amounting to Rs 4,22,129.55 crore.” - Ministry of Defence

This significant push in defense spending indicates a strong focus on indigenization and support for domestic manufacturers.

item.title: Russian surface-to-air missile caused Azerbaijan Airlines plane crash in Aktau: Report - India TV News
item.description:
Russian Missile Linked to Azerbaijan Airlines Plane Crash in Aktau

Publication Date: December 26, 2024
Source: Euronews

Azerbaijani government sources confirmed that a Russian surface-to-air missile was responsible for the crash of an Azerbaijan Airlines plane in Aktau, resulting in 38 fatalities.

  • The aircraft was en route from Baku to Grozny when it was forced to reroute due to weather conditions.
  • A nationwide day of mourning was observed in Azerbaijan for the victims of the crash.
  • Investigation points to a possible missile strike, with conflicting reports about weather and a bird strike influencing the flight path.
“The information provided to me is that the plane changed its course between Baku and Grozny due to worsening weather conditions and headed to Aktau airport, where it crashed upon landing.” — President Ilham Aliyev

This tragic event highlights ongoing tensions and safety concerns in the region, prompting further investigation into the incident.

item.title: Maiden Flight Of China’s ‘Tailless’ 6th-Gen Fighter Storms Social Media; Expert Calls It A Whole New Level! - EurAsian Times
item.description:
Maiden Flight Of China's 'Tailless' 6th-Gen Fighter Storms Social Media; Expert Calls It A Whole New Level!

Date: December 26, 2023

Source: EurAsian Times

Exhilaration and speculation are on the rise following the maiden flights of two advanced sixth-generation fighter jets from China, stirring extensive discussion across social media.

  • The flight took place over Chengdu, with a J-20S believed to be accompany the new jet as a chase plane.
  • This event has been characterized as a “Chinese Christmas defense surprise” by users on platform X.
  • Experts are split, with some suggesting the aircraft might represent a significant advancement in military aviation technology.
  • The new jet is distinguished by its unique tri-engine design and appears larger than the existing J-20 fighter.
  • Another prototype by Shenyang Aircraft Corporation has also reportedly flown recently, indicating intense competition in sixth-generation technology.
“This and GCAP may demand some urgent re-thinking in regards to NGAD,” said Dr. Malcolm Davis, emphasizing the rapid advancements in China's military aviation.

China's latest developments in fighter technology pose challenges for the US and allies, potentially accelerating their own programs.

item.title: India comes to Pakistan- friendly Yunus rescue, to send first shipment of.... - India.com
item.description:
India Sends First Shipment of Rice to Bangladesh Amid Political Tensions

Date: December 26, 2024

Source: India.com

The interim government of Bangladesh is set to receive its first consignment of rice imported from India, representing a significant development amid shifting political alliances.

  • The ship ‘MV Tanais Dream’ will arrive at Chauddagram Port carrying 24,690 metric tonnes of parboiled rice.
  • This marks the first instance of rice imports from India under an open trade agreement.
  • The event follows a recent warming of relations, with ships arriving from Karachi to Bangladesh.
“We will collect the sample of rice after conducting a physical examination and the process of unloading will commence.” - Bangladesh food ministry official

This rice shipment signals a hopeful step towards improving diplomatic relations between India and Bangladesh, which has recently seen fluctuating ties.

item.title: Trump tells death row inmates granted clemency by Biden to ‘go to hell’ in scathing Christmas Day message - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Trump tells death row inmates granted clemency by Biden to ‘go to hell’ in scathing Christmas Day message

Date: Dec 26, 2024 | Source: Hindustan Times

In a recent Christmas Day statement, Donald Trump sharply criticized Joe Biden's decision to commute the sentences of 37 federal death row inmates. Trump directed harsh remarks at these inmates and the Democrats, expressing his disdain and opposition to the clemency granted.

  • Trump told death row inmates to “go to hell” in response to Biden's clemency.
  • The statement came after Biden commuted the sentences of 37 out of 40 death row inmates, many of whom include violent criminals.
  • Trump referred to Biden derogatorily as “sleepy Joe” and criticized the Democrats as “radical left lunatics.”
  • He vowed to “make America great again” in the upcoming weeks.
  • Trump’s comments were aimed at discrediting the Democrats' approach to justice and politics.
“To the 37 most violent criminals, who killed, raped, and plundered… I refuse to wish a Merry Christmas to those lucky 'souls' but, instead, will say, GO TO HELL!” - Donald Trump

This statement highlights Trump's controversial rhetoric and the political tensions surrounding criminal justice in the United States as he prepares to take office.

item.title: US announces release of revised H-1B filing form for foreign workers - The Financial Express
item.description:
US announces release of revised H-1B filing form for foreign workers

Publication Date: 2024-12-12 Source: Financial Express

The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) has announced that starting January 17, 2025, H-1B visa applicants must use a revised version of Form I-129 for their petitions. This form is essential for nonimmigrant workers to apply for various classifications.

  • The new edition of Form I-129 will replace the older version and has no grace period.
  • Once the new form is in effect, the previous edition will no longer be accepted.
  • The changes aim to streamline foreign worker hiring processes and enhance the efficiency of the H-1B program.
  • Petitioners are advised not to submit the new form before the effective date.
“The H-1B program has been modernized with a new rule that streamlines approvals, enhances flexibility for talent retention, and enhances program integrity and oversight.”

The implementation of the new Form I-129 is a crucial step to improve the immigration process for foreign workers in the U.S., thereby supporting the economy.

item.title: Virat Kohli fined 20% match fee on Boxing Day match fee and one demerit point on breaching ICC’s Code of Conduct - The Hindu
item.description:
Virat Kohli Fined 20% of Match Fee for Breaching ICC Conduct Codes

Date: December 26, 2024

Source: The Hindu

Virat Kohli has been fined 20% of his match fee and received one demerit point due to a breach of the ICC Code of Conduct during the fourth Test against Australia.

  • Kohli breached Level 1 of the ICC Code on December 26, 2024.
  • The incident involved Kohli making inappropriate physical contact with Australian player Sam Konstas.
  • Umpires Joel Wilson and Michael Gough were involved in the assessment of the incident.
  • Kohli accepted the charge and the proposed sanctions.
“Kohli was found to have breached Article 2.12 of the ICC Code of Conduct, which relates to inappropriate physical contact with a player.”

This incident marks Kohli's first offence in a 24-month period, and he now holds a demerit point on his disciplinary record.

item.title: Israeli minister’s Al-Aqsa mosque visit sparks condemnation - Arab News
item.description:
Israeli Minister's Al-Aqsa Mosque Visit Sparks Condemnation

Date: Thursday
Source: Arab News

This visit by Israel’s National Security Minister Itamar Ben Gvir to the Al-Aqsa mosque compound in Jerusalem has provoked strong reactions from Palestinian and Jordanian officials, denouncing it as a deliberate provocation amidst ongoing tensions in the region.

  • Minister Itamar Ben Gvir visited the Al-Aqsa mosque compound, violating bans on Jewish prayer at the site.
  • The visit has been criticized by the Palestinian Authority, who deemed it a provocation to Muslims worldwide.
  • Jordan's foreign ministry condemned the actions as “provocative and unacceptable,” emphasizing a violation of the historical status quo.
  • The status quo allows Jews and non-Muslims to visit the compound but prohibits prayer and religious displays.
“I went up to the site of our temple this morning to pray for the peace of our soldiers, the swift return of all hostages and a total victory, God willing,” - Itamar Ben Gvir

In conclusion, Ben Gvir's visit has heightened tensions surrounding the Al-Aqsa compound, a site of deep religious significance for both Jews and Muslims.

item.title: Report: Mossad chief believes Israel should target Iran to get at Houthis; PM disagrees - The Times of Israel
item.description:
Mossad Chief Advocates Targeting Iran to Counter Houthi Threats; Netanyahu Disagrees

Date: December 25, 2024

Source: The Times of Israel

In a recent development, Mossad chief David Barnea has urged Israeli leadership to focus on attacking Iran to mitigate threats from the Houthi rebels, contrasting with the views of PM Netanyahu and Defense Minister Katz who prefer direct strikes against the Houthis.

  • Barnea believes targeting Iran is more effective as it funds and arms the Houthis.
  • Israeli officials indicated plans for increased military activity against the Houthis in response to recent missile and drone attacks.
  • PM Netanyahu maintains that the situation with Iran must be addressed separately in due time.
  • Air Force Chief Tomer Bar affirmed the commitment to intensify attacks on Houthi targets.
  • Former Defense Minister Yoav Gallant supports collaboration with the US against both the Houthis and Iran.
  • The article details ongoing Houthi assaults, including missile strikes that have resulted in injuries in Israel.
“We need to go head-on against Iran,” Barnea stated, highlighting the urgency of the situation.

The ongoing conflict with the Houthis reflects broader regional tensions, as missile and drone assaults from Yemen have become increasingly common.

As the Israeli military contemplates its strategy amidst escalating tensions, the coordination with US forces is expected to play a crucial role in shaping future actions against both the Houthis and Iran.

item.title: New Syria government to demand $300 billion in compensation from Iran over war damage - Middle East Monitor
item.description:
Syria's Interim Government Demands $300 Billion Compensation from Iran

Publication Date: Not specified
Source: Not specified

Syria’s new interim government is set to demand $300 billion in compensation from Iran for the damage caused during the civil war.

  • The compensation is aimed at rectifying harm caused by Iran's involvement in the conflict.
  • Iran had previously supported the Assad regime with military aid and financial support during the civil war.
  • The Iranian Foreign Ministry has referred to claims of debt repayment demands from Syria as exaggerated.
  • Communications between Iran and Syria have reportedly been completely cut off.
“The Syrian people and the Syrian state are seeking compensation for the harm caused by Tehran’s ‘criminal and arbitrary’ policies.”

This demand arises amid strained relations and significant historical debts and contributions during Syria's ongoing civil war.
